Thank you for this video! In the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, in the late 50s and early 60s when I was a kid, they used to have a similar device that worked the same way. It was demonstrated in the Electric Theater. That one was relatively portable (with casters) and smaller: IIRC, the size of a large hassock.

The demonstrator would wheel it on stage and show the levitation of the aluminum plate. He (always "he" in those days) didn't have the light fixture, though. He never mentioned any of the electrical specs, but the machine gave off a distinct hum. He did show that if you pressed down on the plate, the humming would get louder. That showed the plate didn't get that hot in the short demo time, so spraying water on it wouldn't be dramatic (but he did mention the plate got warm). Also, the machine didn't have anything to prevent water from dripping into it.

The Electric Theater was so cool! It was my favorite place. First time I saw strobe lights, UV light, and a microwave transmitter as big as a refrigerator. The last had two small plates on bars on the front (transmitting antennas, I guess), and he had an ear of popping corn on a stick that he placed between them, and the corn would pop on the ear! You could smell the fresh popcorn! Totally magic at the time! Imagine how I felt when compact microwave ovens started showing up around 1970!

He also had a setup that would catch the shadow of an exploding balloon with a synchronized strobe flash on a phosphorescent screen! Now anyone can see high-speed videos of that, but at the time it was completely WOW!!!!!!!
I have not found one video this guy has done which was less than fascinating!

Now what if you can create a strong enough oscillating magnetic field that even lead bullets can be repelled when firing from a gun? Do the math. Assuming you had a superconducting coil and it took no energy when nothing was being pushed, in how small of a volume would there be enough space available to produce a magnetic field strong enough all around the superconducting system so that if a bullet were fired from any direction (except for a special bullet that had an oscillating field too =P) it would be deflected off due to its own oscillating magnetic field? This requires both enough power density to produce the energy quickly enough to slow the bullet down as it approaches the system do that it stops moving before it hits it (use calculus) and energy density, since a particular amount of energy will be required during this process.

I could probably calculate it, but it would take more time than is worth it for me =P. Anyone knowing electromagnetic and Newtonian physics, calculus, and a bit of wit should be able to come up with an answer.

And then as a bonus question, how large of a bullet would be necessary to penetrate the field? Such a bullet would have to induce oscillating potentials in it opposite to the ones induced by the field at the same frequency. And after you realize that any object that wants to approach this system is going to have to be the same size using the same technology, how can you make a conducting system that can approach it aside from sticking in insulators? In fact, can you change the structure of the bullet, say with a spiral winding, so that the current instead produces a clockwise or counterclockwise force that makes the bullet spiral faster at the cost of only some reduced speed? Could you create a system that converts this energy into an electrical current that could be used to store the energy in a lithium ion battery without generating the repelling force?

Maybe one day weaponry will face these challenges =P.

This is part of Lenz's law.  If you drop a powerful permanent magnet down a non-magnetic electrically conductive pipe (like copper or aluminum) the movement of the magnet induces current in the pipe giving the pipe its own magnetic field that opposes the original magnet.  In effect, slowing the decent of the magnet down the pipe.

The changing magnetic field generates 'Eddy currents' in the plate. These Eddy currents create an opposing magnetic field which is why the plate is levitating. Additionally, these currents dissipate heat, since the plate has some resistance. (Not a super conductor). About trains, I think they use superconductors. The cooling is to maintain the 'super conductivity' of the material, because all known super conductor materials need to be cooled to a certain temperature to be a super conductor.

Roughly anyway, in fact the magnetisation caused by currents in wires affecting free charges is a lot "simpler" to explain than stationary bar magnets, whose magnetic fields are caused (essentially) by Quantum Mechanical effects, but the reason aluminium doesn't react to bar magnets is because the applied field of the bar magnet doesn't create magnetic domains in the aluminium like in Iron. This is also relevant: straightdope. com/columns/read/940/why-dont-magnets-stick-to-aluminum :)

There's a difference between "magnetic materials" in the popular sense (i.e you can turn them into magnets/affected by a bar magnet) and materials affected by magnetic fields. Magnetic fields affect free charges, which most metals have lots of! So all the electrons in the aluminium are "unbounded" in a sense and are free to react to the magnetic field and give a net force to the plate. However, "magnetic" objects like Iron are simply that in which the magnetic domains REMAIN after magnetisation

From what I know there is a difference between magnetic materials and metal that levitate due to a magnetic field. You probably know that metals in general have free electrons that can move about within the metal. The changing magnetic field they produce moves the electrons in the aluminium metal, inducing a current as they say. This "induced" current then creates an opposing magnetic field to the original, which i why it levitates. So it could be any metal (not just magnetic).

Needless to say, if the top piece were non-conducting you could not get a current to flow through it and there goes your magnetic field and all the fun.
Now, why does it need to be large-ish? Because large mass makes for large inertia and you don't wont the piece to fall perceptibly between the changes in the current's direction. Granted, 900 Hz means 900 changes of direction each second and that's pretty damn fast, but still. Also, a smaller object might very well melt.

Good point. Aluminium is indeed non-magnetic. However, for this demonstration to work, you need the levitating piece to be a) conducting and b) with a large-ish mass.
You will notice that the coil is isolated from the aluminium piece, which means that any current flowing through it will have been induced by the switching of direction in the coil's own current. Furthermore, it is of such dirrection that its own magnetic field will oppose the magnetic field of the coil, hence the repelling.
